HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 7, 1926.

FOR NEXT YEAR'S JUNIORS
NoW that the tumult and the shouting has died, and the
team captains and) committee chairmen have departed, unfavorable criticism of the banquet season again nilikes its
appearance on the campus. Such a reaction is natural at this
time, when the interest and excitement have died down, and
a record of cut classes with the finals only a few weeks off
is all that remains; with the possible exception of a few
bruises, to remind the participants of the joys of last week.
These complaints are well founded, but we do not think
that they justify either modification or abolition of the banquet
season. Cali it childish or a waste of time as you will, we feel
that as long as the Iundergraduate school remains, the banquet
season has a definite place on'the campus. It is the one tradition of its kind that has grown up spontaneously on the Hopkins
campus; it is practically the only means of creating class- soli-.
clarity; and above all, it's a mighty interesting game.
Its one serious drawback is that it takes valuable time right
on the eve of the examinations; and this can easily be remedied.
Three or four days just before the finals count for a great deal
more than the same number at some earlier date. If the Junior
Class of next year will hold their banquet in the first part of
April instead of the last, the freshmen and sophpmores can have
their music without paying the piper near so heavily.

Nvhich form a small community
have this same problem to deal
with. What can be done to promote interest in, and discussions
of current problems?"

UNNECESSARY CONFLICTS

that drinking was disappearing
from the campus, held a referendum iwo weeks ago. The ques-

If our memory serves us rightly, we distinctly recall that
in the early part of the year great satisfaction was expressed
over the fact that a method had been devised for preventing
conflicts in undergraduate affairs. There was placed in the
Registrar's office a calendar upon which the date of future events
were to be listed as soon as they were planned, with the understanding that as far as posisble no two affairs be held the same
night.
-As far as we know the calendar is still there in good condition ; in fact, from all appearances it has never been touched.
• Last Friday, for instance, was the date of three events—the
annual meeting of the Tudor and Stuart Club, the Junior Banquet, and the Enginiers' Dance. The dance and the Tudor
Stuart meeting, of course, caused no conflict; but the engineers
who attended the Junior Banquet were considerably delayed
in getting to the dance, and members of the Tudor Stuart Club
who were juniors, were forced to make a definite choice between
attending either the meeting or their class banquet.
Although the matter was not one of great importance, it
,-aused a great deal of inconvenience. In he future the men
1`1)'amp arranging affairs would do well te ,nsult the calendar
I efore setting their dates.

tion, -Do you think prohibition
has decreased the amount of drinking in the university?" was voted
on by over two thousand five hundred members of the faculty and
students, and the resnits were four
to one that drinking had increased.
The votes of the students may not
be considered so seriously as those
of the faculty. The former do not
know what the exact conditions
were before prohibition, and as
there was no honor involved in the
polling stuffing the ballot was not
an impossibility, if we may judge
by the Hopkins results. The faculty, however, should "know their
oats," having sowed their wild
ones before 1919.

behind in the wake of a Cunard College Special, bound for Europe and the
time of one's life!
Make up your mind to go, and you'll
count the days 'till the good ship sails.
Think of Paris and London and the
Continent! Like stepping off this mundane sphere into a new world.

One student made the astounding statement that he -was for
modification because the liquor
sold today will kill the working
claiss in ten years. Another was
quite frank in giving his reason
foil favoring light wines and beer.
am not .man-enough to drink.-;-anything stronger."
An underol aduate demands the
repeal of the law because the Cane
Club may go out of existence.
That was counteracted by a ballot
for prohibition announcing -down
with the cane club!" One voter
says that any form of prohibition
tends to enrich the negro and
alien bootleggers. The bad gin
that college men have to drink is
one of the most popular reasons
for opposition to the dry law.
Some students are of the opinion
that prohibition is an infringement on personal liberties.
Among the questionnaires turned in by the upholders of the constitution there are several that
resemble Anti-Salon League slogans. One of these is as follows:
"Women and -song, but not wine."

0. D. K. INITIATES FOUR
JUNIORS

YOU can't always
tellfrom the Campus
T

HIS is a plain tale of a regular, everyday American undergraduate—an engineer
from the University of Cincinnati, with a
college record much like that of thousands
of other students.

He got a kick out of playing varsity
basketball. He caught on the baseball team.
When Cincinnati won at football, he celebrated with the rest. For a year he supervised the student cooperative bookshop. He
was president of the Engineering Tribunal,
the student governing body. In a word,
he did the things well, that college students
everywhere like to do.
But of the specialization which he was
to undertake at Westinghouse—there wasn't
a clue.
The case of W. E. Thau is another
example ofunforeseen opportunities afford2d
by such an organization to a man with a
healthy aptitude for getting things done.
After the usual training given college
men, he entered the General Engineering
Department. Later he became Engineer
in Charge of the Marine Section, handling
all marine and government application jobs.
That was six years ago.
Within Thau's time, the Diesel-electric
drive has come to be the most advanced
method of ship propulsion. By means of

it the man in the pilot house controls his
vessel as easily and surely as the driver of
an automobile. Also, this system uses
about one-third the fuel of the ordinary
steamship--an enormous saving in dollars,
cargo space and weight. Of all the Dieselelectric marine installations in the world
today 7o per cent are Westinghouse.
W. C. THAU

The question is sometimes asked:
When do young men get when they
enter a large industrial organization?
Have they opportunity to exercise creative
talents? Or are they forced into narrow
grooves?
This series ofadvertisements throws light
on these questions. Each advertisement
takes up the record of a college man who
came with the Westinghouse Company
within the last ten years or so, after
graduation.

Thau and his associates determine how
practical is each application proposed. They
diagnose each customer's needs. They
prescribe the right Westinghouse equipment.
For instance, when the Government sent
word: "Electrify the battleships Tennessee
and Colorado," the Marine Section was
on the job to install turbine electric drives,
which helped to make these warcraft the
most powerful units in the National
Defense.
Or the Clyde Steamship Line says:"We
want to load these lumber-cargo carriers
electrically. How can we do it? What
will it cost?" Thau must figure to a fine
point the exact requirements.
Thus does the Westinghouse application
engineer combine commercial and engineering sense to advance the interests of the

customer being served.

School of Hygiene
Awards Fellowships
The School of Hygiene and Public Health has awarded Research
Fellowships, with a stipend of
$1,000, to Howard M. Estill, S. B.
and S. M., who is a holder of a
similar fellowship this year in
Chemical Hygiene, and to W. P.
Covell, Ph. D., in Biometry and
Vital Statistics.
These fellowships have been
awarded for the scholastic year
1926-27.

A few reasons why The Guardian
Life Insurance Company of America is the ideal Life Insurance
Company for you to represent.

to pay all death claims.

to the man who properly fits himself for the business.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 7, 1926.

FOR NEXT YEAR'S JUNIORS
NoW that the tumult and the shouting has died, and the
team captains and) committee chairmen have departed, unfavorable criticism of the banquet season again nilikes its
appearance on the campus. Such a reaction is natural at this
time, when the interest and excitement have died down, and
a record of cut classes with the finals only a few weeks off
is all that remains; with the possible exception of a few
bruises, to remind the participants of the joys of last week.
These complaints are well founded, but we do not think
that they justify either modification or abolition of the banquet
season. Cali it childish or a waste of time as you will, we feel
that as long as the Iundergraduate school remains, the banquet
season has a definite place on'the campus. It is the one tradition of its kind that has grown up spontaneously on the Hopkins
campus; it is practically the only means of creating class- soli-.
clarity; and above all, it's a mighty interesting game.
Its one serious drawback is that it takes valuable time right
on the eve of the examinations; and this can easily be remedied.
Three or four days just before the finals count for a great deal
more than the same number at some earlier date. If the Junior
Class of next year will hold their banquet in the first part of
April instead of the last, the freshmen and sophpmores can have
their music without paying the piper near so heavily.

Nvhich form a small community
have this same problem to deal
with. What can be done to promote interest in, and discussions
of current problems?"

es. The Yale News to disprove

UNNECESSARY CONFLICTS

that drinking was disappearing
from the campus, held a referendum iwo weeks ago. The ques-

If our memory serves us rightly, we distinctly recall that
in the early part of the year great satisfaction was expressed
over the fact that a method had been devised for preventing
conflicts in undergraduate affairs. There was placed in the
Registrar's office a calendar upon which the date of future events
were to be listed as soon as they were planned, with the understanding that as far as posisble no two affairs be held the same
night.
-As far as we know the calendar is still there in good condition ; in fact, from all appearances it has never been touched.
• Last Friday, for instance, was the date of three events—the
annual meeting of the Tudor and Stuart Club, the Junior Banquet, and the Enginiers' Dance. The dance and the Tudor
Stuart meeting, of course, caused no conflict; but the engineers
who attended the Junior Banquet were considerably delayed
in getting to the dance, and members of the Tudor Stuart Club
who were juniors, were forced to make a definite choice between
attending either the meeting or their class banquet.
Although the matter was not one of great importance, it
,-aused a great deal of inconvenience. In he future the men
1`1)'amp arranging affairs would do well te ,nsult the calendar
I efore setting their dates.

tion, -Do you think prohibition
has decreased the amount of drinking in the university?" was voted
on by over two thousand five hundred members of the faculty and
students, and the resnits were four
to one that drinking had increased.
The votes of the students may not
be considered so seriously as those
of the faculty. The former do not
know what the exact conditions
were before prohibition, and as
there was no honor involved in the
polling stuffing the ballot was not
an impossibility, if we may judge
by the Hopkins results. The faculty, however, should "know their
oats," having sowed their wild
ones before 1919.

time of one's life!

count the days 'till the good ship sails.
Think of Paris and London and the
Continent! Like stepping off this mundane sphere into a new world.

T

HIS is a plain tale of a regular, everyday American undergraduate—an engineer
from the University of Cincinnati, with a
college record much like that of thousands
of other students.

He got a kick out of playing varsity
basketball. He caught on the baseball team.
When Cincinnati won at football, he celebrated with the rest. For a year he supervised the student cooperative bookshop. He
was president of the Engineering Tribunal,
the student governing body. In a word,
he did the things well, that college students
everywhere like to do.
But of the specialization which he was
to undertake at Westinghouse—there wasn't
a clue.
The case of W. E. Thau is another
example ofunforeseen opportunities afford2d
by such an organization to a man with a
healthy aptitude for getting things done.
After the usual training given college
men, he entered the General Engineering
Department. Later he became Engineer
in Charge of the Marine Section, handling
all marine and government application jobs.
That was six years ago.
Within Thau's time, the Diesel-electric
drive has come to be the most advanced
method of ship propulsion. By means of

it the man in the pilot house controls his
vessel as easily and surely as the driver of
an automobile. Also, this system uses
about one-third the fuel of the ordinary
steamship--an enormous saving in dollars,
cargo space and weight. Of all the Dieselelectric marine installations in the world
today 7o per cent are Westinghouse.
W. C. THAU

The question is sometimes asked:
When do young men get when they
enter a large industrial organization?
Have they opportunity to exercise creative
talents? Or are they forced into narrow
grooves?
This series ofadvertisements throws light
on these questions. Each advertisement
takes up the record of a college man who
came with the Westinghouse Company
within the last ten years or so, after
graduation.

Thau and his associates determine how
practical is each application proposed. They
diagnose each customer's needs. They
prescribe the right Westinghouse equipment.
For instance, when the Government sent
word: "Electrify the battleships Tennessee
and Colorado," the Marine Section was
on the job to install turbine electric drives,
which helped to make these warcraft the
most powerful units in the National
Defense.
Or the Clyde Steamship Line says:"We
want to load these lumber-cargo carriers
electrically. How can we do it? What
will it cost?" Thau must figure to a fine
point the exact requirements.
Thus does the Westinghouse application
engineer combine commercial and engineering sense to advance the interests of the

customer being served.

The feeling of indifference toward
the .building is heightened by the
prospect of the eventual establish• ment of the New Plan. However,
it is -asserted by Dr. "EdMunds
and felt by many others that the
change will not greatly alter the
status of campus activities.
Even without this objection, the
activities look forward to the new
building with little short of apprehension, for the University, while
promising no rooms as offices, is
considering using at least a part
of the Barn as post office and
press room in the near future.

School of Hygiene
Awards Fellowships
The School of Hygiene and Public Health has awarded Research
Fellowships, with a stipend of
$1,000, to Howard M. Estill, S. B.
and S. M., who is a holder of a
similar fellowship this year in
Chemical Hygiene, and to W. P.
Covell, Ph. D., in Biometry and
Vital Statistics.
These fellowships have been
awarded for the scholastic year
1926-27.

BILL HOLLENBECK, Rep.

A few reasons why The Guardian
Life Insurance Company of America is the ideal Life Insurance
Company for you to represent.
Its great financial strength —its
income from investments alone being considerably more than enough
to pay all death claims.

growth since its birth, in 1850.

its representatives in the field.

highest grade representatives.

7. Its automatic guarantee of success
to the man who properly fits himself for the business.
8. Its opportunities extended to its
field force in advancement.
